Expectation2: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation2: A patient is at a routine check-up and has general questions about their health.
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket just as I sit down with Mrs. Lee for her routine check-up. I glance at the screen and see a message from Sam, my closest friend. His reply is curt, and I can tell he’s hurt—he’s misunderstood my earlier text. My chest tightens with guilt. I know I should call him right now, clear things up before the misunderstanding festers. That’s what friends do: communicate openly, resolve things before they grow. But Mrs. Lee is waiting, her eyes anxious as she asks about her recent bloodwork. As her doctor, I owe her my full attention, to answer her questions with patience and empathy. I can’t rush through this, not when she trusts me with her health. My mind races, torn between the urge to step out and call Sam, and the responsibility to be present for Mrs. Lee. The weight of both roles presses on me, each demanding something I can’t give at the same time. My heart pounds as I wrestle with what to do next.
